Expectation1: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation1: In the middle of jury instructions, your clerk hands you an alert that the Supreme Court has just issued a ruling that directly overturns the key precedent your current instructions are based on. You must stop immediately.
Situation2: They organize an intensive workshop for community leaders to deeply understand and apply complex theological concepts.
Story:
I was standing at the bench, robe heavy on my shoulders, as I read the jury instructions aloud. My mind was focused, every word measured, when my clerk slipped me a note—urgent, trembling. The Supreme Court had just overturned the very precedent I was explaining. My heart pounded. I knew I had to stop, reassess, and ensure the law was followed precisely. The courtroom waited, eyes on me, expecting clarity and authority.

But my phone buzzed in my pocket. The church council was waiting for me to lead the workshop I’d promised, a deep dive into theological principles that required my full attention and presence. They expected guidance, wisdom, and spiritual leadership. I felt torn—my duty as a judge demanded immediate action, legal accuracy, and composure. My calling as a pastor required compassion, teaching, and presence. Both roles demanded all of me, right now. I stood frozen, the weight of two worlds pressing in, unsure which expectation to answer first.
